titleproper.value: Guide to the Edward Eliscu Papers <num>TAM 270</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-10T16:22:26</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Edward Eliscu (1902-1998) was a lyricist, playwright, screenwriter, and a progressive activist in the entertainment industry, notably in Hollywood in the 1930s and 1940s. The collection includes his correspondence, scripts, speeches, articles and photographs.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Edward Eliscu Papers; TAM 270; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Materials were donated by David Eliscu in 2001. The accessio numbers associated with these gifts are 2001.045, 2001.149, and NPA.2002.049.

Edward Eliscu (1902-1998), was a lyricist (best known for <title render="italic">Without a Song</title>), playwright and screen-writer, and a progressive activist in the entertainment industry, notably in Hollywood in the 1930s and 1940s.

The Edward Eliscu Papers contain correspondence, unpublished lyrics, scripts and other literary writings (many of a political nature), copies of <title render="italic">The Spectator</title>, Eliscu's weekly column in the <title render="italic">National Guardian</title>, film, theater and general political ephemera and internal documents, including from several progressive entertainment industry organizations such as the <corpname>Hollywood League for Democratic Action</corpname>, the <corpname>Hollywood Peace Forum</corpname>, the <corpname>Hollywood Anti-Nazi League for the Defense of American Democracy</corpname>, the <corpname>Hollywood Theatre Alliance</corpname>, the <corpname>Hollywood Writers Mobilization</corpname>, and the <corpname>Motion Picture Democratic Committee</corpname>. There is also a speech, written by Eliscu for delivery by Progressive Party candidate <persname>Henry Wallace</persname>at an October 8, 1948 presidential campaign appearance in Portland, Oregon.  Also included in the collection are a set of a dozen cartoons (Defending the WPA), and about a dozen photographs related to the campaign to defend blacklisted screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, and one photograph of Ann Meeropol.

subject.value: Communism and motion pictures -- United States.
Political activists |z California |z Hollywood (Los Angeles, Calif.).
